review_title: Fun and good job during the school semester
pros: Kind Coworkers Plenty of encouragement to improve allowed to attend student events while on the job Work is easy and helps one learn about the ins and outs of the job
cons: None I could see while I was there

pros: Flexible schedule, great colleagues and reasonable pay.
cons: Limited opportunity for full time employment.

job_title: Part Time Adjunct Instructor in Chicago, IL
pros: There are many courses available. Once you get into the system, you can teach at any of the campuses.
cons: Majority of students are not very motivated, especially at low-level courses.

job_title: Talent Acquisition Specialist in Chicago, IL
pros: -diverse staff -good benefits -decent salary -room for upward mobility
cons: -not a lot of bad things

pros: Work with good people and be a driver of creating equity.
cons: -Large bureaucracy -Work is slow -Tense political environment makes it nearly impossible for faculty, staff and administration to work together.

pros: Great employee support, convenient location
cons: job descriptions are outdated, salaries behind industry standard

pros: The pay is great. The people are most of the time great. UNION JOB. Which allows for job security.
cons: Heavy caseload management for advisors; however, remote options are available.

pros: Staff and students are great.
cons: No certainty of hours you're working every semester.

pros: Challenging, dynamic and faced over environment
cons: Minimal raises, and constant changes

pros: Great co-workers, working with students is rewarding.
cons: Low pay, entrenched bureaucracy at the college. The scheduling and reporting software, Navigate, is poorly designed and confusing to students and faculty alike.

pros: I loved the atmosphere and my supervisor! overall a great place to work!
cons: I would have preferred a full-time opportunity

job_title: Adult Education Teacher in Chicago, IL
pros: The diverse student body is great. Students truly appreciate all of the help that you give them.
cons: Administration could not care less about you

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Chicago, IL
pros: flexible schedule great opportunities to network
cons: i have cons to this company

pros: None in my experience there
cons: Very political. Management talked bad about one another.

job_title: College Clerical Assistant II in Chicago, IL
pros: Job Stability and mission driven
cons: Around registration Many long days

pros: Okay okay okay okay okay
cons: Politics politics politics politics politics

job_title: Instructor, College Or University in Chicago, IL
pros: Good quality of life and overall working conditions
cons: Poor management, disorganized, high management turnover

review_title: Administrative leadership is grossly overpaid, underqualified, and hopelessly arrogant.
pros: My colleagues and students make this work worthwhile and meaningful for me.
cons: Constantly changing leadership with no one understanding our students or our colleges; the district leadership consumes an enormous portion of the overall budget (which is primarily funded by Chicago taxpayers), yet they make one terrible decision after another, and then swiftly leave before any accountability sets in. The next ones are equally lacking. It's dispiriting,

review_title: Adult Educator at City Colleges of Chicago
pros:
That said, if you want a part-time job, it's a lot of fun working with and teaching adults. Most people who count on it for their sole source of income wind up frustrated. 

Benefits can be paid into, and a lot of people have "side gigs". It works well for artists!

There are sometimes other opportunities for teachers, such as curriculum development, etc.
cons:
It's a part-time job and there is a lot of time off, but all of it is unpaid. There are only three sick days per year.

It's a large bureaucracy, so organizational change can be slow and difficult.

pros: Working with Faculty to support student retention and persistence.
cons: May be overwhelming at times.

job_title: Transfer Center Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Great commute, and benefits ! The supervisor is a great person to work with too!
cons: There aren't too many cons to working at CCC, except maybe keeping track of all the students and their transfer needs!

pros: None that I can think of
cons: Low pay, no opportunity for job change

job_title: Part Time Cashier in Riverside, CA
pros: cashiering during the day is fun
cons: cashiering at night is not fun

review_title: Abuse of those with a heart
pros: For those who care about poor working class families in Chicago. Benefits and salary are good for full-timers.
cons: City Colleges is drastically underfunded by the city, so rather than get the money it needs to be competitive, district and (too many) administrators punish part-timers who serve a foundational function to the schools, students, and the system.

pros: Great benefits and Great PTO. The PTO is honestly unmatched to any other comapny. No one compares
cons: Pay increases / bonuses are very hard to come by. Also moving up in positions only takes place once some one retires which its a long game you play here.

pros: They’re ok but not the best
cons: This is too long to list

job_title: Assistant Director of Financial Aid in Chicago, IL
pros: salary, moving around opportunity, events for students
cons: Lack of communication, lack of planning before making changes

review_title: There are always pros and cons
job_title: Dean of Academic Affairs in Chicago, IL
pros: Working with students is a pleasure. It was hands down the nest part of the role. There are many great teachers at the campuses. Ability to work without micromanagement and impact change in communities.
cons: There must be a very deep look at the relationship between unions and public sector employment. The relationship cannot continue to be adversarial or it will continue to erode the spirit of our public education systems. Public education is a cornerstone of communities and there has to be more opportunity to work together or I worry about the viability of this critical infrastructure to the city.

pros: The Dean I work under is great. She goes to bat for me when I need it and is there for me when I need help with either a student or being an employee. She sticks to what she knows and let’s me handle my course how I see fit within the expectations.
cons: The school system is so large that there is a massive issue with communication. There’s a lot of red tape everything due to the corruption from years before which impedes meaningful progress in the schools.

job_title: Math and Physics Tutor in Chicago, IL
pros: Students and co-workers are super polite and well educated.
cons: Opportunity for growth is hard to get and salary does not match the investment and quality of work.

pros: its a rewarding and honored opportunity
cons: no cons at all this is a great employer

job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Chicago, IL
pros: Remote work, good mission, excellent chancellor
cons: Some bureaucrats exist and make it less fun

pros:
Flexible hours
You submit your schedule every semester if you need to change your hours
The overall job is pretty easy as long as you know the material, coworkers are friendly to offer support if you need it when working with students.
cons:
You can't work over 25 hrs
No full time option
You can't change your employee contribution after it's initially selected, and if you neglect to selected an option, you'll default to just a 2% employee contribution.

review_title: City Colleges of Chicago - Malcolm X College
pros:
Amazing students
Great colleagues
Supportive union
Central location
cons:
Some faculty, staff, and administrators are there just for a paycheck.
(Just like any place - there are some stars and some rocks.)
If you find your people, it's a really supportive place.

review_title: Just a couple of years after college
pros:
Hardworking and committed students, mostly
If there's any chance you can work full time, this will be one of the top jobs.
cons: Do not plan to work as adjunct more than 1-2 years just for experience. You just can't survive with your income.

pros: The only pro is that you get paid holidays.
cons: Very toxic work environment. If you aren't in the clique you are not treated right. Very poor communication by Administration. It's like they make things up as they go along and penalize you for not knowing. Lack of consistency. Poor staffing. If you speak up for yourself, you will be retaliated against. Union is useless if you happen to have a grievance.

job_title: Student Note Taker in Chicago, IL
pros: Co-workers are respectful and they really help guide you if you are new.
cons: I can't really think of any cons

pros: MXC is a great place to work.
cons: The union contract makes it very hard to foster accountability.

job_title: Adjunct Professor of English in Chicago, IL
pros: Good working environ, dedicated and committed personnel and faculty
cons: I can't think of any yet.

pros: Excellent Care and support from management in fulfilling one’s responsibilities
cons: Transport issue to the working area

pros: Great for students! People around you are willing to help!
cons: No cons, in my opinions.

pros: Great work to start a career
cons: As part-timer you don’t have any benefits

pros: Job Security, average compensation rating, great benefits for health dental etc.
cons: little to no growth as far as a pay increase.

job_title: Senior Research Associate in Chicago, IL
pros: Smart, passionate people dedicated to equity and inclusivity. Everyone is respectful and a delight to work with. The organization lives diversity.
cons: Like any large organization, the bureaucracy/hierarchy can be an impediment to realizing the mission.

pros: English department faculty were great. Most seem to really care about their students.
cons: There wasn't really room for professional development or pursuing professional interests. Feedback was not considered and the divide between faculty and paraprofessional staff is very stark. Limited resources to help students.

pros: good experience in learning systems
cons: advancement might be a little difficult

review_title: Good place to learn about higher education
job_title: Director of Academic Support Services in Chicago, IL
pros: Nice people in all levels of the organization
cons: You can burn out very easily

job_title: Full Time Faculty in Chicago, IL
pros: Large network that is well-connected across the city; strong union; many passionate employees
cons: So much bureaucracy; CCC is not a dynamic institution that can really respond in a timely or efficient manner to student needs

pros: Great place to work, flexible, great boss, work hours are great.
cons: Not much opportunity for promotion

pros: Nice working environment, free parking garage and flexibility
cons: The lack of noodle meal for lunch and dinner

pros: Good place to work in Chicago
cons: Cant think of any at this time

pros:
Cares about students 
Diverse staff 
Relaxed work environment
cons:
Disorganized
Antiquated processes
Short lunch break
Lifetime positions

pros: Good work environment and high morale
cons: Long work hours susceptible to burnout

pros: Great culture compared to other city agencies
cons: Salary increases not guaranteed yearly for non-union staff.

pros: The students and experience makes it worth it.
cons: It can be disorganized and hectic at times.

pros: If giving or receiving work orders, I insure all work is completed in a timely manner.
cons: Not having the necessary materials and or supplies to complete task in a timely manner

pros: Most of your co workers are fun
cons: It doesn't pay a lot

job_title: Professor of Biology in Chicago, IL
pros: Good team, good pay and helpful supervisors
cons: Few full time professor openings

pros: Nothing worthy to mention. You can find something better to do.
cons: No benefits, just an hourly salary which cannot exceed 24/week

pros: Great benefits, impactful work, motivated and authentic colleagues
cons: ever-changing leadership, political, develop your own processes, lacks professional development opportunities, cult

pros: Really depends on the school you are working with. For example Harold Washington vs. Wright College. Different experience. The pro is you can work at any of the city colleges so there is more openings and flexibility. Also the students are not as bad as I think most people claim them to be. A lot of them do want to succeed and move on to 4 year colleges.
cons:
Sometimes its a mixed bag with the students so it is hard to cater to all of them in one course. A lot of them also are quite unmotivated and no matter what you do they don't acknowledge the work you put in. 
Apart from the students you have almost no rights/perks as an adjunct at first. The pay is surprisingly low (~$565/credit hour and ~$775/credit hour for bio adj. professors). For the amount of work you need to put in it sometimes may not be worth it depending on the subject you teach. Also I found it bizarre that there is no reduced fair or even covered fair for transportation. For a school like Harold Washington which is in the Loop everyone has to travel via the L and so if I teach twice a week thats $10 out of my pocket just to get to and from the college. Bizarre.

pros: Great pay, great benefits, great retirement
cons: Must Be a City Resident

pros: Good pay, very easy going, nice people, stress free, faculty seemed to actually care.
cons: What a joke this whole system is.  I'm almost positive that nobody there actually has a clue what they are doing.  Friends hiring friends with no background  or knowledge of the job.  People hiring their children as Part-time to do the work they are supposed to be doing.  Faculty seemed to be the only people to care yet were most likely the least paid.  Chancellor hiring friends and her fellow 'church' members for six figure salaries that never existed before she got there.  The whole mentality of the place is that there is unlimited money from the tax payers, so nothing gets done right and then they just spend away and up the budget for next year.  People move money in the budgets, so it seems money was spent where it was supposed to be but actually wasn't.  Compare this to a private sector schooling system and it will probably be better in every aspect.   Glad to have left there and moved on in my life.

pros: Community focused, economical, accessible, innovative.
cons: None real cons to mention.

review_title: My experiences a City Colleges of Chicago have been educational and professional.
pros: The Pros of working at City Colleges of Chicago (1) Promotional, it is possible to start at the beginning and move upward (2) CCC is one of the largest community colleges in the nation (3) Ongoing partnerships with the City of Chicago and the Mayor (4) Professional & educational diversity with staff, curriculum and students (4) Numerous professional, promotional & learning opportunities for all (5) New community colleges, Malcolm X College (currently I am Dean of Continuing Education), will become Health Science Career forces and School of Nursing.
cons: The Cons of working at CCC (1) Political (2) More administrative meetings than necessary (3) Due to the size of a department, Deans/Directors may not spend much time with students and or staff (4) At times could be considered too large, seven colleges (4) At times, not enough time provided for meeting state and district deadlines.

pros: Being a note taker, is rewarding and stress free from the political nuances of CCC community.  Also the Disability Access Centers are very insightful and goes 120% for their students and staff. Only department that has great cohort relationships with one another and their directors.
cons: The reinvention is the focal point, but they should be reinventing the staff. They are quite the clique, BFF, big brother and sister oriented. The right hand knows nothing of what the left is doing, confusing, and poor customer service at each school.

pros: For many years under the previous Chancellor CCC was inspired and great work was being done. It was an excellent work environment where everyone had an opportunity to make a difference.  That has all changed.
cons:
Former Chancellor lost control. Made the work about her rather than the institution or the students it servers.  Ego got in the way of progress and all of the previous good work was lost.

New Chancellor is looking to make his mark and is almost as driven by ego as the previous Chancellor.  He arrived as a political appointment, with little relevant experience and without a plan.

CCC will be going through a long period of dysfunction until hopefully a new leader will be brought in based on merit rather than political payback.

pros: The experience of working with and meeting amazing chefs .learning new things and getting to show your talents off as well. Meeting different people outside of my race and dealing with others 1 on 1 as a server cook or caterer is what gives me the drive to want to learn more and move up in this field.
cons: The communication and pay isn't very good. The management is always switching over its no stability or room to grow I've learned enough working at Washburn for me to expand on to different things and move up with what I have learned.

pros:
Union Protected position
Health care options (HMO PPO Vision and Dental)
SURS retirement
Life insurance options
cons:
-Little room for upward mobility 
-Adding more to your job description (ie. necessary certifications that need yearly to complete job) but offer no form of additional compensation.
-Not referring to your contract for responsibilities and causes upset when union steps in to hash out the details as they should.
-Lack of communication between departments and misinforming students about  typical office procedures.
-Lack of initiative in departments 
-Lack of management support 
-Always point out flaws without constructive criticism
-Never commended for good work or initiative
-Favoritism within departments (higher and lower expectations within same department)
-Micromanaging

pros: Most of the faculty and staff is friendly and work well together. Some staff and faculty collaborate well togther.
cons: Very toxic and controlling environment. The lines of communication is Very poor. The staff is the last to know about things that directly effects them. No consideration for staff input on decisions made in the nursing department. Administration is incompetent. Most are too concerned with insignificant things when there are more important issues to address. Extremely long process to transition from part-time to full-time. No job growth and no real increase in pay. Hard to get information regarding policies of employment. They seem to make up rules most employees are not aware of. When initially hired they give you the union book and that is about it. Most things in the union book they do not abide by. It is always some excuse when you point out something in the union book and they find a reason to not abide by it. It is very frustrating working here.

review_title: Former employee that left for opportunies in the private sector
pros: Impact lives of many students who come from a wide array of backgrounds. Definitely would recommend to anyone wanting to work in academia at the ground level and really play a part in education
cons: Any big administration in the government will have its set backs and issues it's employees will take issue with. It's just part of the structure of government. You would have to be okay working in government at a government pace. I can't say this is ALWAYS a bad thing as often plans are announced well in advance. Sometimes the delay in implementation can be frustrating if your job would be improved by whatever the issue is.

review_title: Some work study students make more than I do.  There should be a cap on salaries.
pros: Laid back atmosphere atmosphere atmosphere
cons: Work study students should not make more than permanent staff.  Some employees without college degrees make more than employees who have college degrees, because there are no salary caps.  Employees just keep getting raises as long as they continue to work for the company.

pros: The ground level staff is excellent and great people. They kept me there for almost 4 years but after having a life changing car accident I just could not handle the undue stress, anxiety, and hostility anymore.
cons: Terrible on campus leadership. Chancellor is a political appointee so the system has no stability. Each Chancellor comes in with new ideas of how things should be and they change everything because they all want to leave their mark. Leadership cares only about numbers and advancing them selves. The system was 90 million in the hole when I abandoned ship.

pros:
1. High salary, flexible hours and benefits.
2. Keeping the grounds clean and in a pristine order shows my skills and competence
3. Clean as needed whether it’s every day or two times a week. Making sure that things are clean and in the order that they are supposed to be.
4.   Whenever I do something I do it right
5.  . Exceeding customer expectation and receiving additional business due to a job well done and taking pride of a job well done.
cons:
1.	Depending on the person
2.	It takes hard work and force to do so, you have to deal with dirt and mess.
3.	I can get chemicals on my hands and I can get sick.
4.	Doing the messy restrooms.
5.	Appreciating the pride and sight of a job clean and sparking.

pros: Semi Educational environment where rarely the teachers can be very brilliant. Close to commute, acceptable internet speed, better on your ego title for your job. Some very brilliant students who really make you proud before they finish here.
cons: Some very stupid employees, some extremely racist black people, some very lazy teachers. I had to deal with students who didn't learn much in their classrooms, pointing at their exam papers and complaining they got a bad grade. Some students even tried to bribe me to do their homeworks, and some very disappointing few that fills the campus floors with their stupidity and eagerness to show it.

pros: I enjoyed teaching at this college. The department is very collegial.  In my experience, the adjuncts were never treated as second-class faculty members.  The administrative staff was also very helpful and friendly.  I had diverse students, ranging from young, fresh-out-of-high school students to older, returning students.  Some students were academically underprepared, while others were overachievers.  Overall, I had the most appreciative students, which is why I would teach here again if I had the chance.
cons: There is limited equipment for those who want to use technology in the classroom.  Some powerpoint projectors worked, while others didn't.  Compensation-wise, you have to be prepared to receive relatively low pay if you teach only one class.

pros: Serving kids who can't afford expensive universities
cons: Chaotic, and getting worse. Top management living in a fantasy world. The Chancellor has a 19th century management style, disrespectful to most employees, top-down. Yelling.  "Knowledgeable" about technology and emphasizing it instead of focusing on educational goals. Calls big staff meetings for no good reason then shows up late, wasting everybody's time. Technology "improvements" based on personal preferences and familiarity with certain solutions, manufacturers or their lobbyists. Serious resources are being wasted on futile projects.  The damage is being done now but will be felt in the coming year(s).  Stay away.

review_title: Not an ideal place to work
job_title: College Clerical Assistant II in Chicago, IL
pros: You are provided with benefits and flexibility in using your time off.  Good for work/life balance.
cons: Depending on the position, the pay can be great or terrible.  Lower level employees are not paid well and treated as if they are not valuable members of the company.  The administrators do not honor employees with a voice.  No matter how hard you work, it is not appreciated.  A few managers have been known to tell employees that if they didn't like CCC, they can leave.  Opportunities for advancement seems to only apply to administrators.

pros: Pay is above average for part time employment.  Depending on which City College location you are at, immediate management is fair and consistent.  Students have diverse and interesting lives which makes for lively classroom point of views
cons: Management can and will change frequently,   rarely does it seems people are promoted from within  or have actual teaching experience.   Administrators rely heavily on the clerical staff for the day to day operations.

pros: Meet some hard working people who generally care about the students and fellow co-workers.
cons: Lots of political games, butt kissing, and lots of nepertism amongst the hisphanic employees. Too much placating,  and favortism. Incoming black students are not well excepted or respected within the Accessment center.Lots of racial profiling.  Black students and prospective employees please be on look out.

pros: City Colleges is undergoing drastic change at all of its seven City Colleges. Each College is providing training students they will be able to obtains jobs after two years or move onto accredited four year institutions and earn bachelors in specialized areas because they have agreements.
cons: Under the current Re-invention Plans Management does not necessarily listen to advice provided by middle management. High Management level staff require training in how to treat fellow employees.

pros: City Colleges has a great benefits package, although some of the HR staff are incompetent when it comes to explaining them.
cons: The culture is terrible! Processes are long, confusing, and ineffective. It takes weeks, if not months, to purchase necessities. Lots of old-timers want to do things as they always have without consideration to new methodologies or cost improvements. Most people at CCC just want their paycheck and their SURS retirement, they are not interested in improving education. Lack of communication at all levels, and this alone is going to further sink CCC!

pros: Opportunity to make a difference in the community and in a person's educational career.  Employee engaging in the instruction of the person seeking a career can have a positive effect and outcome with award winning results.
cons: Not all employees' are a good fit to serve the college and student of the community.  It is imperative for the employee to understand who they serve without judgement so that they can be effective in assisting the person in achieving their intended goal.

job_title: Call Center Representative in Chicago, IL
pros: Excellent benefits package and union as well as good pay. Colleagues are very positive and helpful. Everyone works together as a team to assist the student. It is a gratifying experience to be able to impact students and help them throughout their academic career.
cons: An overwhelming amount of monitoring.  Not only were our calls being monitored, but we also had a one-one coaching session once a week and weekly team meetings. If you are looking for a position with autonomy, this job won't be a good fit for you. The company is downsizing and has undergone layoffs.

pros: Great benefits:  vacation, salary, holidays, tuition reimbursement, Heath insurance, vision, dental, work hours, retirement benefits.
cons: Political work environment,  limited advancement opportunities unless a member of the "chosen few."  Unprofessional environment.  Earned degreed personnel, but limited critical thinking skills, no teaching experience, racist, poor grammar, poor speaking skills with "ghetto" language, lack of high student expectations and too busy helping students play the system instead of teaching them how to function in the demands of the work environment.

review_title: Okay...If you need a job, grab it and get all you can from the experience.
pros: Solid benefits, you will find many pleasant coworkers (a big plus), and you have the opportunity to help young people who really want to succeed.
cons: Leadership changes, poor communication at times.  I choose to use it as a stepping stone; not a long term career move. The college you work for matters in terms of overall leadership and opportunities.  District Office will most certainly pay a better wage.

pros: Fun staff to work with.
cons: Not willing to listen to all staff. Too much of a high school click type atmosphere.  Director has his/her favorites and it shows in the work ethics of peers. No accountability for those that lack in their work and over work for those who take pride in what they do.

review_title: Collegial, open door, great benefits, motivated by the mission, "Enriching Lives Through Education!"
pros:
Vision; preparing Chicagoans for success,
Mission; exceptional educational services for a diverse and disadvantaged population,
Culture; collegial, family, professional,
Work life balance,
Excellent employee benefits at a low cost to the employee
Outstanding retirement plans,
Generous time off; vacation, holiday, personal and sick days,
The chance to make a positive difference in students lives every day.
cons:
Lacking in structure, organization, process and procedures; the reinvention initiative is actively seeking to address these challenges.

Residency requirement of living in the city of Chicago; should be able to live in the suburbs.

pros: Large network; enthusiastic students! There’s not much more I can say to highlight the company in a positive way- I think the writing on the wall is pretty clear here!
cons: No authority given to manage employment directives, generally disgruntled staff. Overall, poorly managed and poor communication from the top down. Teams are shuffled so inconsistently, it’s hard to establish a chain of command or any semblance of accountability with staff.

pros: Working with students and helping them achieve success. Very hardworking college faculty, administrators and staff.
cons: District leadership does not always understand the impact that their operational efficacy strategies have on the colleges (administration and students).  They need to be more in tuned with what is going on at the college campuses by meeting with college administration (onsite) more frequently.   They must leave the district office to understand what is going on in the "real world" and take appropriate action.

job_title: Manufacturing Technology Administrative Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Had a very flexible schedule and options to work on Saturday mornings. This was a work study job when I attended Richard J. Daley College. The faculty for the most part had good moods and happy to help you if you had any questions.
cons: Wasn't much bad to say my time there, I had a good part-time experience, maybe have a email for any events or changes that would benefit or be of interest to employees.

review_title: This Place Is A Train Wreck...Run Away Fast!!
pros: Good benefits, good mission to help under-served students
cons:
Very poor leadership, incompetent people in high places, baggage laden leadership. Many folks in senior leadership roles are from CPS and the problems seem to follow them....apparently they never learned how to figure out what a "common denominator" is. Politically charged atmosphere. Very miserable and toxic environment. 

Hiring processes take months and months, procurement takes even longer. Senior leaders want to run things like a corporation but they have no clue, which coincidentally is why they're at CCC....no corporation would hire them

CCC is becoming a diploma mill....they are only looking to increase graduation numbers for political purposes.

pros: Rewarding work with students; diverse workplace with people of all ages and backgrounds; faculty and staff are good people with good attitudes
cons: Lots of turmoil from downtown; very political upper management downtown; lots of managers are egomaniacs who care more about how they are perceived and not how programs work for students

job_title: Assistant Business Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: I whole heartedly believe the Chancellor and other leadership are committed to providing affordable and quality education to our surrounding communities. I have been involved with many meetings and strategies that definitely prove that fact. The benefits offered are good and the vacation time is great.
cons: There are some departments where operations are not of the best quality and could be improved. For example the accounting software and its usability.

pros: Work with people and change their lives.  Give input to future policies and feedback to improve technology for use in your profession.  Access to top management.
cons: The cons vary from campus to campus but their is constant change to policy, procedure, and there hasn't been a norm created as of yet.  Still in reinvention trying to find an identity.  There is no promotional or advancement opportunities from within.  Large caseload (Varies by campus)

pros:
Benefits are great  i.e. vacation, breaks in between
Pay decent
A sense of purpose because of the students that you serve
cons:
Policies are extremely laxed therefore employees do whatever they want without any consequences.
Maintaining integrity is frowned upon.
High turnover-mostly created by the bad decisions of senior management
Limited to no opportunity for promotion.....need not apply only if we like you- hint hint

review_title: Future faculty: Embrace being micromanaged and bullied. Smile. Don't ever get sick. Always smile.
pros: I made some great friends and has moments of gut busting laughter.  I enjoyed the privilege of getting to know some very fascinating people.
cons: The employment situation was always precarious. The environment was unprofessional in the sense that several staff members have been verbally abused without opportunity for recourse. Bullying environment.

pros: relatively good benefits and secure work. If not in management position can be union and limit unpaid overtime. Some work locations are pretty easy to get to.
cons: in order to have anything done you have to go through unfortunate layer of bureaucracy, lots of waste and poor results.  Can be frustrating if you care, otherwise it is 'just a job'.

pros: Stimulating, challenging work. Support from management. Best part is working with students and employers. It was exciting to be there during "Reinvention" and the launch of College to Careers.
cons: High Stress levels. Mangement especially demanding and employees to manager levels expected to be on call most of the time. The HR dept. is problematic for most hiring managers.

review_title: Students are the core of the college my first priority is to give them the best services, resources and tools to succeed
job_title: Computer Lab Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Interacting with students keeps me motivated.  I make it my goal everyday to help a student beyond what is required of me.
cons: Career Opportunities are scarce and administration is constantly changing

review_title: Exciting time of innovation and change at Daley College.
pros: Best part is working with many talented colleagues who are creating improvements in academic programs, student life, student services, and business partnerships. Daley's innovations include new tutoring services, better adult remedial programs and expanded services.
cons: Intense workload. The result of the regime change has been better student outcomes and better enrollment but some staff have low morale due to increased workload and the leaving of long-time colleagues.

pros:
Union membership
Advisors have spring break off 
Health insurance is ok
Some opportunities for growth
cons:
Union membership - lazy employees cannot get fired (i.e. Anthony Moore)
Revolving management door
Parts of leadership team are not very good
Clocking in/out four times

job_title: Student Services Professional in Chicago, IL
pros: I enjoyed my time in Student Services immensely! The students are valued and education is a priority! In addition, providing students with a community of support proved to be effective in their success! Great Benefits and time off! The culture of this community was awesome!
cons: Poor teacher and student boundaries! Other than that, I didn't have many complaints!

pros: Tutoring at Wright College as a student offers flexible schedule, great working experience, positive atmosphere, chance to connect to teachers, opportunity to help other students and utilize knowledge.
cons: As a student tutor, you can only work 20 hours a week and benefits are not included. However, this is very convenient way to make extra money on campus

review_title: Student Mentor-Tutoring students in Microsoft Office Suite.
pros: I have the opportunity to help students learn how to effectively use software and complete assignments in Microsoft Office Suite. It is rewarding to see them improve their learned skills and pass their classes with very good grades.
cons: The downside is when some students just don't try, and some give up. Also the pay rate could be better

pros: The hours were flexible enough that it allowed me to be home before and after the traffic was bad.  It was also located in a area The was accessible to public transportation.
cons: Not enough hours the pay was low - times when school was closed and of course you don’t get paid.

review_title: Changed a lot for the worse lately
pros: Before things changed for the worse, this used to be a unique entity with own solutions, with great versatility of environments and jobs and we were able to learn a lot at work.  It offered free tuition to immediate family, great respect for employees and their family needs (changed a lot for the worse lately).  Most people there used to have an opportunity to grow and advance positions within college/location or at  different locations.  Everybody worked together like and better than one family, always keeping students' benefit in mind as the ultimate goal.
cons:
The new management is encouraging copycat approach instead of creativity.  They apply what they've learned at their previous locations and jobs without learning the actual situation of this unique institution and they are acting like elephants in a china shop.  

I was a Deputy CIO with a success story of advancing up the corporate ladder throughout over 14 years of loyal and exemplary public service.  The new management recognized all that with a barely 13.5 days layoff notice upon which I was escorted from the building by security.  No advance notices, no severance, nothing.  They did the same to another Deputy CIO with about 30 years of service instead of telling him to retire, so the day after he was escorted he had to rush back to HR to change his status from laid off to retired.   If they treat their faithful managers like that, you can imagine what kind of treatment their "regular" employees are getting nowadays.  

Some key players who worked there with me or for me have already resigned or retired.  This also includes people from other colleges, college presidents, etc.  Most people I know there are now trying to leave.

review_title: Bad Managed Office of Information Technology - Political, backstabbing, outdated technology
pros: Good pay, good location, good benefits.
cons: Incompetent executive director from Chicago Public School and backward management style. CIO can lie to your face thinking you are not smart enough to know she is lying. No creative problem solving encouraged or any flexibility at all. Political. Backstabbing. Boring. Factory-like environment. Run from this place under these IT leadership.

pros: Awesome people. Great perks to working for the city. Most campuses are located by public transportation, so commuting is easy. Helping students grow and develop is a treat.
cons: Sometimes hard to communicate with different departments in different buildings. The employee database is not always up to date, but that happens with so many employees. Some of the facilities are getting old. Technology can be lacking in certain areas.

review_title: A Big Joke at the Taxpayer
pros: If someone has an argument for the "pros" of working at CCC as an adjunct instructor, please make one.  If an adjunct is teaching nine hours, (three classes; only one less than a full-time instructor) you can expect to make $1100 a month, no health benefits, unpaid office hours (you will hold way more than you teach because most of the students are developmental and demand that level of academic care), and constant economic anxiety that will leave you apathetic after a few semesters.
cons:
-Nobody graduates
-All educational initiatives from higher are made in vain because just how do you organize your instructors to hit instructional goals when 75% of them are hired smester0by-semeseter--meaning, the bosses don't care about the students and are only talking enough education smack to keep their jobs
-The presidents, deans, and other supervisors preside over a deeply broken system and spout the Stalinist propaganda that comes from above to keep their own head from rolling.  They are deeply cynical.  Paycheck grabbing seems to be OK amongst upper-echelon administrators.
The practice of putting academics dead last and having such little care for your teachers (as CCC's hiring practices and adjunct compensation attest) is really starting to show and students have stopped coming.  After one semester, smart students pay the out-of-district fee and head to a better junior college system--just ask Triton, COD, Harper, etc.
-Once the financial aid disbursement checks are mailed to the students, or "kickbacks" the taxpayer flits to keep students attending and the lifers in union jobs, the said students disappear
-Smart counts for nothing; bowing down to the politico of the times counts for everything
If you were sane, you would never allow your children to attend CCC.
-The chancellor, presidents, and deans don't care that 75% of their teachers are living in poverty.  They also see no problem with impoverished teachers teaching impoverished students.
-One day the Feds will start asking questions about the disbursement of financial aid
-It is hard to be inspired once you realize they don't care an inch about you or your students
-Full-time faculty will still not remember your name after you have taught with them for six to eight semesters.
-Like a full-time professor told me, "The only way to survive at City Colleges is to be a one man show."
-There is no way to advance if you are a teacher; in fact, you have little motivation to ever change your lessons.
-Many adjuncts think they will get that full-time job if they work hard enough, which they never get, but they are snitches and keep CCCLOC, the adjunct union, weak as nursing home coffee.

job_title: Reference Librarian (Part Time) in Chicago, IL
pros:
Meeting and teaching students from diverse backgrounds.
Working with professionals and staff members dedicated to student success.
Supporting community projects for students and residents in the surrounding neighborhoods.
cons:
Stressful work environment. 
Many employees felt overworked and underpaid. 
No job security for part time/adjunct librarians.

review_title: Great city job with excellent benefits.
pros: The pay is great. The environment is laid-back. Not sales oriented so no stress to meet any goals. You get to help others achieve their goals.
cons: Truthfully, I have t found any downside to being an academic advisor with the city colleges. It's much better than my old advising position with a for profit college.

pros: Able to get promoted and work in various departments.  Good benefits and the salary is decent.
cons: You can make more with our degree if you work in the private sector, but it helps for you to love what you do.

job_title: Director of Public Relations in Chicago, IL
pros: Good diversity among students, staff and faculty. Campuses are situated in diverse Chicago neighborhoods, which makes for unique partnerships with various colleges. (There are seven in all.)  Great students overall!
cons: Historically, staff hirings were politically motivated given Chicago's long practice of nepotism and cronyism in government. Political hiring has resulted in pockets of incompetence and a lack of professional development, particularly among support staff .

pros: Full health benefits, 403(b) & 457(b) investment plans, paid vacation/holidays and City Colleges tuition waiver. Plus, enjoy working with a group of people who really love what they do. For a more detailed overview of benefits visit our benefits page.
cons: I cannot really think of any cons at this time. I will be sure to add some if they come up.

pros: amazing new facility, technological investment, co-workers, opportunity to impact students, low stress environment (mostly)
cons: union issues, disparate pay across campuses, overly-dependent students, pay

pros: Serving the student population is the most exciting benefit!
cons:
1) Based upon my experience, administration pretends but does not truly value the personal well-being or professional contributions of its instructional staff
2) Claims that the assignment of instructors' classes are strictly based upon student enrollment. However, teaching assignments "appear" to be entirely "subjective" and based upon administrator bias, personal preference, cronyism or nepotism (Decisions in this regard rarely ever "appear" to be based upon work performance or merit)
3) Unfortunately, If you apply for unemployment compensation, it often "seems" that City Colleges of Chicago will actively explore ways to deny, contest or obstruct your "legitimate" eligibility for benefits
4) Only "seems" to recognize the contributions of employees with inside connections to administration
5) Approximately 85-90% of its entire staff are part-time workers(Hypothetically, this "appears" to ensure that City Colleges of Chicago saves money by excluding the typical benefit packages associated with full-time work)
6) I and others have experienced an existing lack of job security(In my view, if you work as an instructor particularly at Kennedy-King or Olive-Harvey College you will work fewer hours or teach fewer classes than at Wright, Truman, Daley or Malcolm X College)
7) Based upon my experience and personal viewpoint, C.C.C. Administration absolutely despises its Adult Education instructors (Adult Educators). I also "believe" that it is highly instrumental in establishing a district-wide caste system or hostile work environment between Adult Educators and the remaining college departments.
8) I  "sincerely believe" that there is no chance for career advancement or upward mobility with this employer, particularly if you are an adjunct instructor, no matter how exemplary your work performance. Advancement opportunities or current positions "appear" to be typically filled with relatives and friends of administrators. Barring either of these alternatives, it then "seems" that positions are infrequently filled by "outsiders" not residing in the State of Illinois. Rarely ever, it "seems," that promotions occur from within! 
9) Based upon my experience, it often "appears" that all of the C.C.C. colleges are not treated equally it terms of financial or academic resources(In my opinion, colleges that cater more heavily to at risk "urban" student populations such as Kennedy-King and Olive-Harvey receive less support and fewer academic resources while colleges such as Wright, Truman, Daley and Malcolm X receive far greater support) 
10) In my view, City Colleges of Chicago is one of the most abysmal employers on record.

review_title: Conider very carfully under the current Political Climate.
pros: Making a difference in the lives of young adults.
cons: Very Political atmosphere.  There are people placed in positions at CCC that are not qualified  to perform the duties of the position and CCC's  current financial condition and declining enrollment.

pros: Sharing my skills and experience with the students is the most important reason to work at this community college.  I learn new skills while I pass on my own to students of all age brackets & life experiences.
cons: The lack of funding for enhancing the students educational experience.

pros: The pay is great for the 30 hours of work required. It leaves plenty of time to get a part-time job, teach adjunct, or just go shopping.
cons:
The place has it politics, manipulators and outright liars hidden in every corner just waiting to pounce on you. They get rid of people who work too much or care too much. They don't want anyone who will reveal their lazy poor work ethics. No one really gets away with poor politics, they just cause others to lay in wait till they can get back at them. It's a vicious cycle. 

Very few teachers actually care about the students. More are interested in protecting their turf and what ever they have going on behind the scenes that scores them extra income.

The district office makes the decisions. The satellite colleges have no input in the decision, all thought they will ask for input and say there see we asked for input, then ignore it. There are no executives with an education terminal degree at central office. They make decisions based on data, but refuse to say what the population size of the data or if the data was a good fit for their decision. 

The model is not a sustainable model. It was nice to focus on the graduation rate and put a few tools in place to boost the rate. Then move on, there are too many issues that are being ignored by focusing everything on the graduation rate. You cannot have a 100% graduation rate. 

Programs are being eliminated that are the backbone of the economies in Chicago. Apparently, it seems the programs will all be eliminated until they reach ground zero, and then rebuild out of the ashes. But until that day comes, CCC is currently going down in fla

review_title: Demand the Most Pay the least
pros: Lots of classes to teach around the city.
cons: Everyone who has never taught your subject will judge your teaching.  Pay is low, yet they demand nearly full committment.  The culture is toxic.

pros:
teaching is awesome
coworkers too
most workers are unionized
cons: dealing w/ strategic initiatives, which are not shared with your average worker bee, based on where the grant money instead of what might actually benefit students; top down leadership that discredits long term employee input

review_title: Teach for any place in Chicago but here!
pros: Better then being unemployed is about the only one I can think of.
cons: There is a great deal of nepotism and favoritism. Who you know is a much greater determinate of your success than anything else. I worked there for over five years and NEVER was my pay calculated properly. It was nearly always short. There were times I waited over 6 months to get a payroll issue resolved and get my pay up to date.

review_title: Horrible, Horrible place as an Administrator
pros: There are obviously some good people
cons: Unfortunately, it's not nearly enough to overcome all the people with president or chancellor in their title who have no idea what they are doing. The current leadership is comprised of way too many former consultants and CPS hand-me-downs. The environment is highly political with the mayor essentially running the Chicago community college system. The pay is decent compared to other community colleges in the area, but it's not worth your sanity.

review_title: A hostile culture coupled with a lofty mission
pros: Innovation is underfoot.  There is always a new program to challenge your professional growth and skills.
cons: Little operational insight or control to pull off any of the innovating programs or projects in its entirety.  Constant infighting just gets tiresome.

job_title: Student Office Assistant in Chicago, IL
pros: Depending on what department you go into CCC is a welcoming and accomodating environment. As a student worker they were flexible in working around my school schedule.
cons: Some student workers are paid the federal minimum wage instead of the local minimum wage. I was lucky enough to be employed as a student worker who made 15/hr.

job_title: Student Services Professional in Chicago, IL
pros:
able to really focus on education and helping students succeed
students come from all over the world--truly a muticultural experience
faculty care about students
Good sense of collegiality
cons:
New chancellor wants to focus on jobs as opposed to education--too much attention paid to numbers rather than actual policies that would be beneficial.

District office is dictatorial and non- transparent, and oftentimes makes well-intentioned but illogical, bad decisions.

pros: The only pro that I can think of is that I do not have to do yearly performance reviews because we get the same raise every yr since we're in a union.
cons: We are in a union so most of the people you deal with are lazy or incompetent. But our team is very good. The 3 best phrases/words to describe CCC: under-staffed, over-worked, and under-appreciated.

pros: Allows student, faculty, staff contact. Potential for further development and growth, advancement.
cons: Unfair hierarchy, political engine, and 'favoritism' discourages professional advancement for qualified employees, good/loyal employees on all levels. No checks & balances.

review_title: Good for beginning a career in teaching
pros: If you are into teaching, this is a good place to start your career. However, be careful that full-time employment is generally not available
cons: Adjunct instructors don't get benefits, salary is meager and there is no opportunities for growth.

review_title: I lead small project teams and lead strategic initiatives across the district.
pros: A lot of appetite for change in the air. Leadership is making a serious investment in changing the outcomes for students.
cons:
Accountability has yet to really sink in across the board. This makes it very challenging to actually get something accomplished.

Most tenure faculty

pros: Benefits and Salaries are good
cons: For administrative positions, it seems like the majority of positions are now held by people with no previous higher education background. Consultants have been brought in from various sectors to take over six figure jobs to which they have no prior experience. Major decisions are made at the district level without consulting professionals at the colleges.

review_title: It was the best of times .... it was the worst of times
job_title: Coordinator I (College Testing) in Chicago, IL
pros: It was very family orientated and friends. I have made a lot of great friends.
cons: Although it does happen from time to time... it is no longer a company where they hire from within.

pros: As a city worker you are required to join the Pension program for full time employees.
cons: Politics, lack of cooperation between each of the schools and the district, stone age technology

review_title: The take the Community out of Community College
pros: Nice newish building.   Many people are very nice.  Work is not hard.
cons: They forget their service is education.  The business people care more about not spending money than helping students be their best.

review_title: This organization is highly political and will suck all of the knowledgeout of the people who actually are competent.
pros: good pay for administrator. excellent benefits
cons: highly political. people in high positions who know nothing about education

pros: Great fellow adjuncts that truly care about students even thougt most (not all) students care more about their financial aid checks than their education.
cons:
Adjuncts treated as second-class by administration and full-time faculty.  If you need assistance with something like a projector, you can expect attitude from the support staff.  In fact, you can expect attitude from most non student facing employees.

Course scheduling each term is inconsistent and "favorites" get the better classes and schedules.

review_title: Decent place to work w/ good supervisors
pros: Union job, good pay, solid amount of downtime before budget cuts made it really nice. Liked my bosses a lot, only left because I moved away.
cons: Part of a big bureaucracy (City Colleges of Chicago), and hours got cut dramatically and suddenly thanks to COVID.

pros: Compensation as a contractor was lucrative. Location to Union Station was convenient.
cons: Internal departmental politics were toxic.  Irrational leadership from management. No methodology to create projects. Need to work nights and weekends due to poor planning.

review_title: It's a big, bureaucratic organization in which you can find good, dedicated people.
pros: You're really helping a lot of people and contributing to something that's really needed.
cons: Needed change is hard because of politics and bureaucracy

pros: The position allows you to be in the state pension plan even as a part time employee. The hours are nice.
cons: As a member of campus police you will have times when there is nothing going on but still need to keep alert.

pros: A two-year college offers abundant opportunities for students (including adult learners).  A great majority of the faculty members care about the students.
cons: Poor leadership, lack of interest in the students, highly political environment, high turnover of leadership, poor communications, high salaries for the leadership--leaving little money for the programs

pros: It is truly rewarding to be a part of a system that has helped millions of Chicagoans change their lives for the better.
cons: It is a large system, and it is easy for good intentions to get lost.

review_title: Storekeeper, responsible for the daily shipping and receiving of parcels to and from the campus. As well as all fixed as
pros: Decent medical and dental benefits.

review_title: This place is a god-awful mess.
